classDescription:
Class Description: Weekly moderated sessions of a teen-led Minecraft Virtual Community! Participants will play together during set times. They discuss rules and coordinate their efforts and goals of their community. This is run by the teens with minimal adult interference. The current culture is of cooperation, negotiation and trading of resources. Trolling and griefing are not tolerated. Ages 10+ 

This Survival Realm launched December 2022 as a CIRCLE class. It is hosted by Rachel (aka “Katarilla”, 13 years old) who has been building and moderating in Minecraft for 4+ years. Due to demand for this class and schedule changes, we are trying a new strategy of splitting into two sessions per week.

Scheduling: There will be TWO sessions available, please only sign up for ONE of them. Either Tuesays from 3-5pm or Fridays from 3-5pm. Students are welcome to play at any other time EXCEPT FOR 30 minutes before and after the Alternate Session Times. EX: if you’re in the Tuesday 3-5 session, you can be on the server any time EXCEPT FOR Fridays 2:30-5:30. Outside of session times, players can join until there are 10 on the server (the server capacity). Players may coordinate play for other times and are limited only by the server capacity. 

Requirements: This class is geared towards experienced Minecraft players (10 and up) with good verbal and some typing communication skills who enjoy cooperative online play in a survival based realm on Easy Difficulty. Participants should know how to craft, mine resources, build and fight off mobs. A set of headphones with a microphone is required to reduce background noise in group voice chat.

Communication: Voice chat will take place on a CIRCLE Milwaukee Discord server. Please arrange a time with Sara in the days before the class to set-up your discord and connect Minecraft accounts prior to the start of class. We prefer not to take class/session time to do this. If you have not participated before, please log in at least 20 minutes early on the first day. All participants’ parents may listen in to "supervise".

No-call, no-show policy will be strictly enforced per Circle policies because of the high demand of this class. We will have a wait list. 

Tuesdays Group Dates: 9/5, 9/12, 9/26, 10/3, 10/10, 10/17, 10/24, 10/31, 11/7, 11/14, 11/21, 11/28 (no class 9/19)
displayLocation: Discord/Minecraft, Online
supplies: A PC or Tablet with the Bedrock version of Minecraft and Discord app downloaded. A set of headphones with a microphone. (please note: realms don't work with Java Edition)

classTitle: Cave Exploration at Ledge View Nature Center
classDescription:
With a naturalist, students hike to Carolyn's Caverns, a natural cave system in Silurian dolostone. They descend a ladder to enter, and are guided through the cave system, learning the geology and biology, with plenty of opportunities to crawl and explore in passages. The more fun they have, the dirtier they get! If the caves are wet, this means mud. Cave visitors wear long sleeves, pants, and closed-toe footwear (no sandals). A soft knit cap is recommended to protect the head from bumps. Cave visitors also bring their own flashlight.

You are invited to meet at the nature center at noon for a BYO picnic lunch in their outdoor pavillion. If you do not wish to bring a picnic lunch to enjoy on site, then please plan to arrive for the start of the cave tour program.

The cave tour program will begin promptly at 1pm and will run approximately 2-2.5 hours. Please be aware of the potentially significant drive time to the cave location depending on where you are coming from. 

The nature center closes at 4pm and so we will need to leave by then, although the program itself will end before 4. 

This program is geared toward students ages 7-15 approximately. Slightly younger children may attend but only if they can descend a ladder into the caves independently and remain in the cave system for the full course of the program. Slightly older students may attend if interested. No one aged 5 or younger is permitted in the cave. 

At least one parent/chaperone per family is expected to attend and go into the cave with the group. 

Please wear long sleeves, pants, closed toe shoes, and a soft knit cap to protect your head. Bring your own flashlights. Plan to get dirty!
displayLocation: Ledge View Nature Center, W2348 Short Road, Chilton, WI 53014
supplies:
Wear long sleeves, pants, closed toe shoes, and bring a flashlight! 

Bring a picnic lunch if you choose to meet early to eat at the center.

classDescription:
Does your tween/teen like to make costumes and dress up in their own creations? Or do they want to? This group will be teen-led and adult facilitated. Four sessions will be for planning, sourcing, refining and then wearing their creation! * Please note the locations vary for each class.*

This class is aimed at students who have some inclination of creating cosplay. Students may have some sewing or crafting experience OR be excited to learn. Younger siblings are welcome to attend, please bring a library-appropriate activity to do, or feel free to wander in the library during class time for the first and third classes. Younger siblings may also participate at their level with parental assistance, but do not count towards “participant” count. 

9/8 – Location: Wauwatosa Library, Firefly Conference Room
– Planning: We will have some examples of project boards and collecting project ideas, and color swatches. We will review some ideas of upcycling and creative sourcing for materials. We will briefly discuss budgeting for your idea. Time will be allowed for brainstorming and planning. Kids with sketching skills may help those who want someone else to draw out their ideas or descriptions. Participants will help each other with formulatitudeing ideas and planning. 
– Supplies: Bring drawing paper or a notebook, writing instruments, any pictures or other things that represent an idea you might have for a cosplay. Any materials you may have already started (optional)


9/29– Location Goodwill 18605 W Bluemound, Brookfield
– Sourcing: Goodwill Meet-up for sourcing upcycled materials. Wander the racks with your cosplay idea in mind and help each other find pieces to fit your vision. Attendance for this date is not required, but notification if you don’t plan to attend is required. 
– Supplies: a budget for your project, your costume idea in mind or on paper


10/13 - Location: Wauwatosa Library, Firefly Conference Room
–Refining: Mid-project meet-up. Bring what you have so far. Get help and refine ideas. Sewing and altering help will be available. We will discuss challenges we have run into and brainstorm solutions. Share resources. Some instruction on costume makeup and face painting will be available, and students may practice with face paint (with parental consent.)
– Supplies: your project as-is so far, materials you want help with, your project planning board/binder/book, face paint and/or costume makeup for your project (optional)

10/27 Location: TBA (Wauwatosa/Brookfield)
– Show and Tell: Wear what you made for an outing. Costumes need not be fully complete. Some cosplay can take months to refine and take shape. This is just the beginning! The participants will have the option to talk about their creation and describe challenges or something they learned, or what they hope to do next. Presentations are optional and can vary from a short statement to a presentation not exceeding 2 minutes. We will meet somewhere that you will have the option to purchase drinks or food, but it wil not be required.
displayLocation: Varies. 9/8 - Wauwatosa Library, Firefly Conference Room. 7635 W North Ave, Wauwatosa, WI 53213. 9/29 - Goodwill 18605 W Bluemound, Brookfield. 10/13 - Wauwatosa Library, Firefly Conference Room. 7635 W North Ave, Wauwatosa, WI 53213. 10/27 - TBA (Wauwatosa or Brookfield area).

classDescription:

classDescription:
We'll be making tinder bundles to use as fire starters. 
It's a really simple process that uses up the dead weeds from your yard and you can use throughout the year to help quickly start a fire. 
Each participant should try to bring some materials - for this we want old dead plant material that is somewhat woody (so that it'll last and will burn when ready to use), but isn't too thick or difficult to bend (so that we can bundle it). You can also bring things to wedge inside the bundles, such as very small dry pinecones or dryer lint. 
I'll supply the twine to tie the bundles together at the end. 

We will meet at the fire pit at Glacier Hills County Park, near the playground. A Washington County Parks Pass is required.

classTitle: Tween/Teen: Radio Milwaukee Shadow Day & State of Sounds
classDescription:
Participate in a half day shadow opportunity at independent radio stations, Radio Milwaukee / 88Nine / HYFIN. Shadow opportunities offer young people an immersive and interactive look into a day in the life of a Radio Milwaukee team member. 

Here's an anticipated schedule of the day: 

2pm Arrival + tour begins 
- Students have the opportunity to talk to staff across multiple departments about their responsibilities and vocational journey 
3pm DJ time with Marcus Doucette
- Sit in with one of 88Nine or HYFIN's on-air personalities for a portion of their shift 
3:45-4:00pm Chill out 
- Students regroup and have 15 minutes to use the restroom, rest, or ask questions 
4:00pm Music Meeting 
- Students gather in our conference room to listen to songs that have our team split. They will break the tie and decide what songs are 88Nine and HYFIN material.
5:00pm Doors open for State of Sound 
- Students come downstairs to take their seats for State of Sound 
6:00pm Students depart 

Due to the size limitations of the group please anticipate dropping off your t(w)een for this experience to give as many spots to interested t(w)eens as possible. The class organizer will be on-site. 

Colectivo Coffee at the Foundry (170 S 1st St, Milwaukee, WI 53204) is a block away from Radio Milwaukee and may be a good place to hang out while waiting for your t(w)een as well as exploring the Third Ward or 2nd St with or without siblings. Feel free to check in during the 3:45pm break and come for the State of Sound show at 5pm.
displayLocation: Radio Milwaukee 220 E. Pittsburgh Ave. Milwaukee, WI 53204
supplies: Please wear clean clothing that isn't pajamas. It doesn't need to be business casual, just not the typical "homeschool uniform."

classDescription:
Día de Muertos isn't another Halloween; it's a Mexican holiday rich with tradition. We'll learn about Day of the Dead at Humboldt Park.

While the focus of the class will be learning about the holiday and its traditions, you're also welcome to bring pictures or mementos of a loved one who has passed away. Feel free to share some fun, heartwarming or funny stories about them in a light and joyous way.

Our hope is that Jason Gonzales will host the Bay View Community Ofrenda again, and after our class you can visit it and display your picture(s) there, if you'd like. Last year, there were plastic sleeves that you could slip your photo into before clipping them to the ofrenda. For context, we brought one photo in particular to display along with marigolds for each of our other deceased loved ones who we wanted to honor and remember.

While death will clearly be discussed, the tone of the class will be warm, not somber, in the spirit of the holiday.

classTitle: Become a Dog-Body-Language Detective! Dog-Bite Prevention Presentation & Workshop
classDescription:
Dogs are amazing animals and have the potential to bring an abundance of joy into people's lives!! Most dogs are also very strong, fast, and have extremely powerful jaws!! Since dogs are such a popular pet in our communities it's really important for people (owners and non-owners) to make the time to learn more about dogs as a species and how they communicate. Dogs don't have a spoken language like we do, however they do have rich emotional lives, and they often "wear their emotions on their sleeve". Almost every single body part on a dog has a story to tell! All we have to do is pay close attention and look for clues to tell us how they're feeling. Please join us for a presentation and workshop on reading canine body language to reduce the chances of your kids or you being bit, and to set yourself and your family up for safer, more enjoyable interactions with willing dogs!! Class is geared toward school-aged kids but all people will benefit. (FYI: No live dogs are permitted at this location.)

Amy was a Certified Professional Dog Trainer and trained/taught at the Wisconsin Humane Society and private practice for 10 years, and completed an apprenticeship and post-baccalaureate academic program in humane, science-based dog behavior and training/psychology. She has been a guardian and trainer to many dogs and one pot-bellied pig/wild boar hybrid.

Create granny squares this fall, then swap your completed granny squares with friends! 

You can use your new squares to start a friendship blanket, scarf, or other fun creations.

Your squares can be any color/theme (within Circle guidelines). The only guidelines are to create 6 inch squares using worsted weight yarn. This will make joining the squares easier.

This swap is for tweens, teens, and adults. Once we have a number of people in the swap we'll determine an amount of granny squares, not to exceed 20.

We will meet at Blum, but may change to the library if the class size is too large.

If you can't make the swap date, no worries! Give me your squares ahead of time and I will 
share them at the meetup for you and gather your new squares.

If this session goes well, we will do it again over winter to grow our friendship creations!

classTitle: Transcripts, High School, College Credit ... Oh My!
classDescription:
High school is one of the most daunting years and some of the most freeing years of being a home-based private education program administrator (aka homeschool mom or dad). 

Let's gather for an early morning video chat of the WI laws surrounding home-based private education programs "homeschools" , and some resources for transcript writing, high school planning, and gaining college credit. 

This is geared towards those filing a PI-1206 rather than public schoolers at home (Bridges, RVA, etc), but all are welcome regardless of the ages of your kiddos. 

I'll be in my pjs. Video as you are.
displayLocation: Google Meet
supplies: Internet connection for google meet.

classTitle: A Mom Teaching Other Parents to Knit Session #1
classDescription:
Grab your yarn balls, some pointy stick things, and join me to learn to knit. You've all been asking, and I'm delivering! 

This class is meant for adults who don't know how to knit, or who would like to get better. (If you're an experienced knitter, feel free to join us at the meetups, but don't register. Save the seats for the newbies.) Babes in arms are welcome, but otherwise please leave the kiddos at home. 

I will walk you through the whole process from choosing needles and yarn, to casting on and binding off, and all the stitches in between. We will meet 3 times, and I'll be available via text or Marco Polo for help in between.

You will have 3 options for easy beginner projects, I'll provide the patterns and help you navigate them. Choose from:
1. Cowl
2. Scarf
3. Hat

I put the end time for 7pm because Fiddleheads closes then, but you may leave earlier if you need to.

** This group will be offered in two different sessions, each is 3 classes. Feel free to sign up for just one session, or both. They will be listed separately on the form. **

We will likely find a favorite spot to revisit a few times during the autumn and we may explore new areas too. Our walks will be relatitudeively short, and we will leave a lot of time for free play at our destination before heading back to our starting point. classTitle: Tween/Teen Hangout - Sports, Hike, or Craft
classDescription:
Tweens/teens join us for an opportunity to build friendships, challenge yourself, and have fun! There will be teen-led activities to get us started, and then it will merge into hangout/free time. Tweens/teens can pick a group to join and work on a skill or learn something new. A group sport will be featured each week for those interested, such as flag football, kickball, archery, sand volleyball, rugby, or soccer. A group crafting/board game circle will have some basic supplies for drawing/art and board games. Please encourage your tween/teen to bring a game to play or supplies to work on their favorite crafts and even enough to share if they would like to teach others. A group can pick a trail to explore and do a hike together. 

We will respect your child's comfort level on participating while creating an environment to give them an opportunity to build relatitudeionships, sharpen communication skills, and support one another. Multiple activities will be happening at once, and everyone is welcome to join whatever interests them. 

This class is held at the same time as Terra Trails so families with multiple ages can offer a class to their older kids at the same time the younger kids have peer-relatitudeed activities. This class is recommended for tweens/teens 10 and older, and while parents are welcome, they are not required to stay. Because of the older age and activities, please reach out the facilitators if there are concerns with your tween/teen needing assistance/supervision, as they will be welcome to explore the park, trails, and participate in activities with their peer group without direct adult intervention. 

While attendance at enrolled events is encouraged, we do not want to discourage anyone from signing up for the class due to its frequency. It is ok to enroll in this class knowing you may miss a couple days. Please notify the facilitators if your tween/teen won't be there so we don't leave anyone behind as we explore. We plan to meet from 11am-1pm every other Tuesday starting 9/5. Please dress for the weather as we will be enjoying the outdoors. We will meet at Minooka Park in Picnic Area 3. We may occasionally explore a different area of the park and will send out a location change ahead of time. Please check email/FB before leaving the house due to possible weather cancellatitudeions day of.

classDescription:
Bi-monthly moderated sessions in a Minecraft Virtual Realm dedicated to the circle class. The players will create goals and community rules (with help of course!) together on their first session. They will play and work together with interference/aid from an adult as needed.

This Realm will be held as a peaceful, survival realm. There will be no monsters or nighttime--and inventory will be kept. This will allow them to learn the building/mining/resource managing part of the game without the stress of the dark or monsters.

The recommended age group for this server will be 6-9 (Beginners are welcome!). Children 10-12 can sign up as well, however there is a moderated Minecraft server geared toward children 10+ with minecraft experience that I would suggest looking into before signing up here.

Each child participating will need access to discord. There is a well moderated Circle discord you will be invited into where we will have our own channel for Voice chat during the session. Your player will also need a headset with a microphone that can connect to the device you're using discord on, this will reduce background noise during the gaming session. I will contact families before our first session to help everyone get set up and answer any questions.

Sessions will take place on the following Wednesdays from 10:30 am to 12:30 pm: 9/13, 9/27, 10/11, 10/25, 11/8, 11/22

classDescription:
Terra Kids, based on the concept of forest schools, will meet in the same natural location so that our children will learn the area and feel more comfortable exploring and to observe changes in the environment, connect with nature, and explore through interactive free play with other families while building community.

Terra Kids will be a primarily child-led group, with parents acting as mentors and guides. As such, we will be following our children's leads as we help them to explore. Dependent upon the day's desires, along with the weather, we may build forts, dams, play in the creek, climb trees, play nature-based games, or just explore. As each family and each individual is different, we respect that each family's needs as to what they are comfortable with as far as roaming and exploring goes may differ. Chances are that we will get dirty and muddy, wet and messy. Please dress appropriately.

Ridge Run County Park, with its evidence of glacial activity, is a 140-acre long narrow park. The major feature is a winding ridge (esker) formed by a subglacial river during
the last ice age. The Park is located on the interlobate moraine where the Green Bay and Lake Michigan Lobes of the Wisconsin Glacier met. Scattered throughout the Park is geological evidence of this event. http://www.co.washington.wi.us/uploads/docs/ridgerun2.pdf

We will meet at the park center parking lot. Feel free to bring water bottles and snacks or lunch and stay and play afterward. Terra Kids is open to all ages.

Note: While attendance at events in which your family has enrolled is encouraged, we do not want to discourage anyone from signing up for the class due to its frequency. classTitle: Vintage Vault Arcade - Chat with the Owner and Play Vintage Arcade Games All Day!
classDescription:
Come for an afternoon of all-day play at Vintage Vault Arcade! Vintage Vault Arcade is just that - a vintage arcade with over 125 "old-school" arcade machines! The owner has spent years researching, locating, and repairing vintage arcade machines with the passion to bring this fun to his community! So, "Let's Go!" and enjoy an afternoon together! 

James, the owner, will begin the afternoon with a short 15-20 minute talk with us on what it has taken to bring his passion to life. He will share the fun and challenges of running a small business and even tell us about the research, restoration, and repair of these classics and some rare and hard-to-find arcade machines. James will then be available all afternoon for any questions and to help make sure we enjoy the fun!

Each person (adult or child) who would like to play will pay $10 for unlimited play and access to over 125 arcade machines, including Donkey Kong, Atari Poll Position, Pac-Man, Dragon Saber, Midway, and ssssoooo many more! Our CIRCLE Event is from noon to 3 pm, but your $10 pass will cover you for the entire time Vintage is open that day, 9/15/23 (Vintage Vault is open Fridays, noon - 10:00 pm), so you can leave and come back if you are in it for the long haul or truly stay all day and play! Each machine has been set up to play without the need for quarters or tokens! There will be tables set up for us outside under an awning overlooking Phantom Lake. We are welcome to bring snacks and drinks to keep outside at our tables for "snack breaks" or bring in closed drink containers to get you through the marathon matches. 

If you can't make it right at noon but still want to join us - feel free! This CIRCLE rate, and all-day play for this event, is $10 per player (usually $20 per person) if you sign up here, pay, and arrive anytime between 12-3 pm. 

This event is open to all ages! (You know your kids best!) Feel free to contact Vintage Vault Arcade for more specific information on the games available, but James mentioned his clientele is usually 8-80 years old! 

Come to play with old friends and new friends and hear a bit about a new, fun, niche, local small business! 
"Let's Go!"

classDescription:
Come join me for the Educator Open House at the Museum of Wisconsin Art! 

This is one of my family's favorite museums. I reached out to the MOWA and asked if homeschool educators would be welcome and her answer was an enthusiastic yes! 

MOWA's event is a drop-in event, starting at 10 and ending at 2. We will plan to meet around 10 (though if you need to come latitudeer, please just let me know!) The event at MOWA is free-flowing and we will play it by ear as to what our group will do. 

The event at MOWA includes: 
*Meet exhibiting artist and educator John Fleissner as you enjoy drop-in art making
*Experiment with classroom-friendly approaches to street art
*Pick up free resources to inspire student learning
*Enter to win door prizes and receive a voucher for complimentary membership that offers unlimited access to experience new exhibitions, enjoy lectures, and dive into educational opportunities for a full year
*Connect with educators over complimentary refreshments

This event is free for all K-12 educators, administrators, student teachers, and school staff (and homeschool educators - I checked!). The first 50 attendees will receive a tote filled with indulgent treats and surprises (this is through MOWA not me).

When we are done with our time at the museum, you are welcome to head home if needed. Otherwise, join us for a 10 minute walk (or 3 minute drive) to Cafe Floriana (https://cafefloriana.com/) to keep some conversation going over lunch. (Did you know that MOWA members receive one 2-pack cookies free with purchase at Cafe Floriana? It's a member perk!)
displayLocation: Museum of Wisconsin Art - 205 Veterans Avenue, West Bend, WI 53095 and Cafe Floriana - 611 Veterans Ave #104 West Bend, WI
fee: No fee collected through CIRCLE,; pay for your own lunch if joining us for lunch
supplies: None

classDescription:
I've partnered with Field Trip Academy to bring this three month course to CIRCLE! 

Field Trip Academy leverages the power of technology and real world science projects to deepen kids understanding of the natural world. 

In this class, you will have access to The Field Trip Academy’s online videos,
content lessons, hands-on activities, and resources. You will have information to learn at home ahead of time, then we will come together for the hands-on portion, then afterwards, you have resources to follow up with at home. I will create a google classroom so that we can share information, questions, pictures when we are not together for the hands-on portion. 

This class is for all ages and includes content for teens and tweens. My own kids are 8 and 11. If we are a larger group, we can split into smaller groups on location for the activities, then come back together at the end. (Example: We might split into older kids and younger kids.)

Each month has a different theme and in this Fall 2023 Session of Circle, we will be exploring the following: 

September: Aquatic macroinvertebrates

Aquatic macroinvertebrates (macros) are small organisms that live in streams.

Join us on a field trip to Jacobus Park (Wauwatosa) to catch and identify macros and use them to measure the stream’s health!

Be prepared to get wet! For our location, water shoes and bug spray are highly recommended (but optional). Younger learners will likely need some help collecting.

Supplies:
● Basic kitchen items (dish, ice cube tray, cup, and spoon)
● Small “aquarium” (or other water) net (if you don’t have one, one can be purchased from stores such as Meijer for less than $5) 
● Magnifying lens
Writing/drawing supplies, journal - Optional: clipboard

October: Fall Leaves

Join us on a field trip to Sanctuary Woods (Wauwatosa), where we will spend time exploring fall leaves. You will complete a group Fall Bingo scavenger hunt, sketch in a nature journal, and create a mandala from found natural elements.

Younger learners will likely need some minor assistance for the Fall Bingo.

Supplies:
● Collection bag(s)
Writing/drawing supplies, journal, Optional - clipboard

November: Winter Plants and Seeds 

Join us on a field trip to Sanctuary Woods (Wauwatosa), where we will learn how to identify common types of plants in their dormant/dead state and forage for seeds to learn more about seed dispersal methods.

Be prepared for the weather - I think we all know November in Wisconsin is unpredictable.
Supplies:
● Nature journal & writing supplies - Optional: Clipboard
● Hand lens or Pocket Microscope 

There are some materials that you will need to print for our field days - but I don’t want lack of a printer to keep anyone from participating! I will reach out before class and find out if anyone needs me to print extra copies for them. 

The class fee is $45 and covers all course materials for the entire three months. This is paid directly to Field Trip Academy. They have put together a special module for our group - instructions about how to access this will be emailed to you after fees are collected. 

Location notes: There is one pipe that needs to be climbed over to get to our location at Jacobus Park, but there is another less direct more accessible entrance and I will send out instructions for that entrance as well. Also, Sanctuary Woods does not have an actual street address, but I will send out a map and instructions for reaching the parking area.
repeats: October 16th and November 20th - Location for both is: Sanctuary Woods - it is on an unnamed road, the closest address is 9480 W Watertown Plank Rd, Wauwatosa, WI 53226
fee: No fee collected through Circle - $45 one-time payment to Field Trip Academy

classDescription:
Terra Kids, based on the concept of forest schools, will meet in the same natural location so that our children will learn the area and feel more comfortable exploring and to observe changes in the environment, connect with nature, and explore through interactive free play with other families while building community.

Terra Kids will be a primarily child-led group, with parents acting as mentors and guides. As such, we will be following our children's leads as we help them to explore. Dependent upon the day's desires, along with the weather, we may play at the natural play area, climb trees, play nature-based games, or just explore/hike. As each family and each individual is different, we respect that each family's needs as to what they are comfortable with as far as roaming and exploring goes may differ. 

Chances are that we will get dirty and muddy, wet and messy. Please dress appropriately. 
**All ages welcome! I will be bringing my 6 year old son. 

**Wehr nature center has a small natural play area and several trails to hike. Let's meet at the play area next to the building and either take the shorter (0.5mi) family friendly hike, or the longer (1.5mi) hike. Bathrooms are located in the building. There is a $5 parking fee for non members.

https://friendsofwehr.org/
displayLocation: Wehr Nature Center - 9701 W College Ave, Franklin, WI 53132
supplies: Proper dress for the weather

classDescription:
Want to keep swimming strong through the colder months? Come play with us! Goldfish Swim School is a family-friendly facility dedicated to kids ages 4 months to 12 years old but older siblings are welcome too. The “deep end,” which is in the middle, has a depth of 4-foot-3-inches, and the shallow end is 3-foot-6-inches. It does not have a tricked-out water playground or water slides. What it has is wonderful 90° water with submerged swim platitudeforms that will keep your kids active and swimming. Pay an annual membership fee of $25 per child up to a maximum of $50 per family or pay a daily fee of $5 per child up to a maximum of $15 per family. Parents and caretakers swim for free. Coast guard approved floatation devices are welcome. Lifeguards are always on duty. Want to swim more? Family swim is offered from 12:45 PM - 1:45 PM on both Wednesdays and Thursdays year round.

This class is being offered in September, October, November and (December - winter session). Attend all, or attend one, just note which ones in your sign-up.
displayLocation: 12565 W Feerick St Brookfield, WI 53005
fee: None - Make payment directly at GSS.
supplies: goggles (to encourage swimmers to submerge their faces, also available to borrow for free), swimsuits, towels, after-swim snack

classTitle: Hispanic Heritage Month Celebration & Dance Class
classDescription:
Let’s celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month! 

Bring scissors and a water bottle, and dress for playing outside! 

Activities will include: 
- Baile Folklórico Dance class
- Bilingual Spanish/ English story time 
- Outdoor games both incorporating Spanish language and games played in Latitudein America 
- Papel picado craft 
- Traditional “Lotería” Game 

Feel free to pack a lunch if you’d like to stick around play at the park afterwards.

I believe this activity will be best suited for children ages 10 and under, though older children are certainly welcome if interested.

classDescription:
‘’Eisenbahn” is the German word for railroad and the trail is built on a former railroad corridor. 
The Eisenbahn trail includes a 5 mile paved path through West Bend. It is a beautiful trail that goes along the river as it takes you through the city. There are fun little stops and sights throughout. My older kids will be leading the group, Lucas (15) and Brandon (14). We recommend that any bikers under 12 bring an adult. I will be walking behind if other parents and younger kids want to join.

We will meet at the Barton Mill and the bikers will head out from there. We would expect this to take around an hour to complete, but it could be a little longer. Bring your water bottles!

supplies: Bike and water bottle

classDescription:
Let’s get together and talk about Unschooling/Life Learning! This group is for families currently following the life learning philosophy and for those who are interested in learning more about what we do. Everyone is welcome! If the kids don’t want to listen in on the conversation they can roam the library and socialize amongst themselves. This will be an open discussion group that we will let unfold organically but keep with a life learning theme. 

The group meets monthly, Sept 21st, Oct 18th and Nov 15th. We will gather in the Children’s/Teen section of the library.

classDescription:
This is a hand stitching club that will meet once a month to learn different hand stitching techniques, and to work on different projects that your children will be so proud of. In the month of September, we will be making hand stitched pencil cases that we can store our loose writing utensils. October we will hand stitch our very own mask, so come prepared with your creative ideas to make a mask unique to you. Lastly, in November, we will put on a puppet show with our handmade puppets that we will make, if time allots, so prepare to become puppeteers! (Don’t worry, this part is optional for those who may be shy).

This class is suggested for ages 6-13, but if a younger child is interested, I would recommend parental guidance. If an older child displays interest in any of the projects, they are more than welcome to participate. If there are older children who would like to assist with the younger children, I can definitely use the help, please reach out or place!

*These classes are listed separately on the calendar/enrollment form, which reoccurs every 4 weeks. You do not have to sign up for all three classes, choose the ones that you feel will interest your child. Also, since we had our intro class in the summer, I will give directions first, then branch off to demonstrate stitches our new faces. I would recommend that new attendees bring a few swatches of fabric (preferably felt, any thick material, or clothing you do not mind destroying) to practice their stitches on.

After class, there is a park nearby, called Coopers Park that we can meet and have lunch. I don't think I've been before, but it looks nice!

(This class will be held at a religious facility, but it will remain a secular event.)

classDescription: Join us for a tour of a honey farm! Learn about how bees make honey and honey extracting process on a family farm of beekeepers. This tour is free and appropriate for all ages. The tour lasts about an hour, and there is a store wheee you can buy honey products afterwards.

classDescription:
Are you between the ages of 13-18 and sick of going to meet ups where you are ten years older than everyone else? Then this hang out is for you! *insert finger guns and tongue click here* 

Join us fellow awkward teens to hang out and hopefully make some new connections. There will be music...There will be games...There will be activities...There will also probably be some awkward standing around staring at our feet trying to figure how to life....but no worries! Bring on the super weird ice breakers!!! We got this! *insert supportive thumbs up here*

We will provide the venue, the drinks and the fun.... think escape room style scavenger hunt, trivia, and party games. Participate in what you enjoy or sit back and watch the chaos. We are good with either! There will be no forced socializing.

We ask that you each bring at least one dish to share for the potluck. We will send out a sign-up genius to avoid an overabundance of desserts.....not that that would be the worst.

The park has bathrooms available as well as soccer fields, volleyball courts, and a basketball court. Feel free to bring sports equipment, camp chairs or other activities you enjoy. 

The cost is $10 per teen. 

If you do not have a county park pass, no worries! A parking pass code will be sent out before the event so you do not need to pay the parking fee. 

Not super cool with leaving your teen with us random peeps? Have younger kids who need something to do? Feel free to bring a picnic, explore the park, hike the trails, fish in the pond, or check out the playground....or sit in your car with binoculars spying to see if you kid is talking to anyone! Come on parents, we know you do that! We don't blame you but it's still kinda weird.

classTitle: Dungeons and Dragons for Younger Kids
classDescription:
If your child has a vivid imagination and enjoys playing pretend, this is a good place to practice those skills! DnD is a table top roleplaying game that incorporates the use of dice rolls and roleplay to craft unique and engaging adventures.

I will host age-appropriate adventures that will offer the chance to roleplay their characters, solve problems, and create memorable stories together through improv.

Each class will be held as an independent adventure so if players are unable to make one class, they will be able to jump back in fairly easily. Part of the first session will be focused on creating and understanding our characters.

These sessions will be geared toward children aged 6-10, older siblings and children are still welcome to join if they are okay with simpler story mechanics.

Supplies and snacks will be provided(feel free to bring your own snacks and drinks too!). Children are encouraged to dress up as their characters if they are inclined to but it is also not required.

DATES:
September 25 2023 - 12-3:30 PM

October 16, 2023 - 12-3:30 PM

November 13, 2023 - 12-3:30 PM


Disclaimer: There are dogs that live at the residence. They will be locked away during the sessions but those with allergies and sensitives to dog noises please keep this in mind when signing up.

classTitle: Tour the National Weather Service Office
classDescription:
Weather forecasts are a critical part to homeschool activities. Let's see where it all happens, consider a career in meteorology, and tour the National Weather Service office. 

It's a small office, so we'll try to split into 2 groups by age - one group will tour and one will hang in the parking lot with some card games and then switch. 

Good questions and behavior appropriate for an office is a must. 

The tour will be canceled if severe weather requires all hands on deck in the weather office.

classTitle: Concord General Store & Zoo Field Trip
classDescription: Let’s go on a field trip to the Concord General Store & Zoo! This little gem is tucked away right off the highway in Oconomowoc. We will meet to feed the animals and explore the general store then picnic for lunch! The store has food options for lunch to purchase as well if you prefer in addition to a coffee bar. Join us for a chance to connect with nature, animals, and community!

classDescription:
Has your child ever wanted to learn to paint like a master? Well, this class is for you! An experienced art teacher, and owner of Create with Heart, will be teaching the "ins and outs" of an acrylic, fall painting on an 8x10 canvas. The teacher will focus on basic technique and mixing colors. Some of the design will be drawn by the teacher ahead of time and some stencils will be used to make things a little easier for younger artists. The teacher has a great winter, paint project in mind to build upon these skills in the next session of classes.

The class is geared towards 6-year-olds and older, but we can work with any age if your child really wants to paint. 

Typically, paint-and-sip classes involve adult beverages, but we will be serving milk, cider and hot chocolatitudee. 

Finally, I am working with the West Bend Library to have the art displayed during the month of October. It sounds promising but I don't have a final yes...yet :)

During this session of Book Explorers (formerly known as Early Chapter Book Discussion), the biography genre will be presented with an emphasis on discovery and utilizing multiple resources. 

If you have attended this program before, you already know that we like to hear about books and often take other people's suggestions. Please bring a book that you have already read or currently reading (does not have to fit with the theme each meeting) to tell us a little bit about it. 

Each Book Explorers will begin with a short oral story and end with an activity.

Note, all the discussions are voluntary and no one will be required to speak.

classTitle: Fungus Among Us - New Fane Trail Edition
classDescription: Interested in learning more about fungi in the wild? We will take a hike and provide information on fungi we pass and those that grow locally that we may not see. As an avid forager with a deep interest in mycology, we will also point out other wild edibles as we pass them. We will take pictures (if you have a camera), draw, answer questions and enjoy the nature around us on our hunt. After concluding our hike, we can have a lunch picnic (not required and please bring your own food) and further discuss. All ages welcome, although the content may be best served between ages 4-13.

classDescription:
The whales and fish are calling you, so come and explore the Shedd Aquarium in Chicago. The aquarium's focus is sparking compassion, curiosity and conservation for the aquatic animal world. You will be able to see beluga whales, coral reefs, dolphins, and maybe even pet a few underwater friends!

See https://www.sheddaquarium.org/ or more information on the Shedd Aquarium's exhibits. 

Our entire group must be present BEFORE 11:20am in order to enter with discounted tickets, please keep this in mind. I put 5pm as the end time because that is when the aquarium closes, but you are free to leave whenever you want.

Weather dependent, there may be an opportunity to feed some stingrays, this is an extra $5 per cup of fish. Families will need to pay for this in-person on the day of.

Attendees responsible for their own parking, the museum suggests these lots: https://www.sheddaquarium.org/plan-a-visit/getting-to-shedd

classTitle: Shadow Drawing At Lynden Sculpture Garden
classDescription:
Let’s see some sculptures and let’s use the sun to make shadow drawings of them at one amazing place:
Lynden Sculpture Garden!

The Lynden Sculpture Garden offers a unique experience of art in nature through its collection of more than 50 monumental sculptures sited across 40 acres of park, lake and woodland.

We can enjoy the outdoors, see some art, talk about the weather and enjoy their beautiful landscaped grounds. 

We will have some books we can read about the sun, shades and art overall so we can seat down and enjoy some nature time while we draw and see how the shadows move within the time we are there. 

Bring a lunch if you want to stay and hang out some more.

Jelli's is a family-run "You-pick" farm. They grow everything from corn and asparagus to strawberries, blueberries, apples and pumpkins. 

This is for ALL AGES.

We will go on a "fall fun tour." Learn about apple and pumpkin production on the farm, see how they harvest and store fall produce, pick your own apples, meet the farm animals, participate in fall activities and games!

$7/participant, chaperones are free unless they also want to pick apples. When you register please list number of participants who will be picking, fees will be collected based on this number.

Each participant will receive a small bag of apples to take home. Optional $2 extra for a mini pumpkin pie (pay on-site, not with CIRCLE registration) There is also a farm store where they sell produce, baked goods, and other items for purchase if you wish.

Inspired by the kids' book "Dragons Love Tacos", we will have a taco potluck, make your taco however you like. We will also create some taco- and dragon-themed crafts.

classDescription:
Every year, I try to give my kids (now ages 7 & 7!) one of those "beginning of the school year" quizzes about their likes / dislikes. What are their preferences for this year, and how are those preferences different from the previous year?

If you are like me, sometimes the discussion doesn't happen until latitudeer in the year (such as October 5!).

Class Description: We will read I Love You the Purplest by Barbara M. Joosse. Then, either on their own or with your help (depending on dictation / writing skills), your kid(s) will answer questions. Questions as basic as: What is your (current) favorite food? To more complicated questions such as: What is your goal for this year? (We will discuss some of the ideas ~ favorite summer adventure and favorite autumn activity ~ and others will be answered individually)

Afterwards, there is a lovely paved walking path and / or a playground. We will be enjoying a picnic lunch, though you may leave whenever you choose. 

The class is located at Fox Brook Park, which requires either a daily fee or a yearly pass for the Waukesha County Park System.

Crunch some leaves, spy some wildlife, navigate some trails. Seminary Woods, adjacent to the St Francis de Sales Seminary since 1855, is 68 acres of beech and maple woodland. It is home to white-tail deer, birds, and the endangered blue-stemmed goldenrod. There is a hidden cemetery a short walk in from parking where we will try to find the oldest grave marker (respectfully, of course).
We plan to walk rain or shine. Maybe not downpour rain. But it can get muddy and some kids love to play in the creek so prepare for all possible conditions.
Parking directions will be sent closer to the day of the hike.

classTitle: Stabbing Things in the Woods (a fiber arts workshop)
classDescription:
All ages, tween-led class during Feral Kids Camping. 

Bring your stabbing projects - needle felting, knitting, crocheting, or any other craft around a campfire project. Hot water will be available for tea and coffee BYOCC (bring your own cup and chair)

classTitle: With Lots of Love Book Club
classDescription:
Join us for another Terra Kids Book Club Add-on! 

This time we will be reading With Lots of Love by Jenny Torres Sanchez. With Lots of Love is a story about a girl who has moved to the United States from her home in Central America, away from everything she leaves behind and longs for- especially her Abuela. Rocio does her best to adjust to a new way of living, but there are many things she misses from her old life – Abuela’s cooking, Abuela’s piñata creations, Abuela’s warm hugs, and of course, Abuela herself most of all. But Abuela finds a way to send Rocio something special just in time for her birthday – a gift wrapped with lots of love – and that fills Rocio to the brim. The themes of familial relatitudeionships, food, celebrations, and connecting with loved ones over long distances in With Lots of Love will be sure to inspire and comfort young children and families all year long!

This book selection is this year's Jumpstart's Read for the Record! Jumpstart’s Read for the Record is the world’s largest shared reading experience and celebrates and supports children’s early language and social-emotional development. Over 26 million people have participated - and this is CIRCLE's chance to be a part of it! Because this is a Jumpstart Read for the Record book, I do have the option to order special edition copies at a discount - please indicate if and how many you would like. If we order enough copies, they will be even cheaper. 

After we read our story, we will discuss the book as well as parts of the story and our favorite foods and important people. We will also learn how to write letters (or draw pictures for younger kids) and how to address and stamp an envelope. I will provide the stamps and envelopes and even mail them when we leave class! Parents, I suggest you bring addresses so your child can practice writing the address (or you can show them how you would put it on an envelope, for pre-writers). We may do a few other fun activities relatitudeed to the book as well. 

This class overlaps with Terra Kids, but is open to anyone. Last time it worked really well to have kids enjoy their lunch or a snack while we read.

classTitle: Nocturnal Flyers at the Mequon Nature Preserve
classDescription:
Due to their nocturnal lifestyle, owls and bats have some of the most unique survival adaptations. An indoor lesson will cover the incredible physical and behavioral specialties of both bats and owls that allow them to navigate the night skies, as well as their benefits to humans. This lesson culminates with a dissection of real owl pellets! An outdoor hike will take the group to a forest that hosts resident great horned owls as well as numerous bats.

This program is being offered for free by the Mequon Nature Preserve to the homeschool community at large. Once I know how many participants we have from CIRCLE, I will coordinate with the Nature Center's educator. Afterward, I will have a more exact details which I will communicate to the group (the time listed on their website may include a lunch break, etc). classTitle: Fill the Trunk! Service Work Opportunity
classDescription:
Fill the Trunk! This is a service work opportunity to help those who are currently struggling. 
Help us fill the trunk of our minivan full of blankets, personal hygiene items, clothing items, etc. 

My family will deliver the items to Street Angels in Milwaukee. Street Angels is a mobile outreach organization assisting our neighbors without homes in bridging the gaps between homelessness and housing through support, advocacy and community collaboration. Founded in 2016 by two women who began voluntarily serving from the back of their cars, the organization has since grown to be a highly regarded leader in street outreach with two outreach buses serving 100-240 individuals three-nights per week. Street Angels has 3 Full-Time and 3 Part-Time staff members and an army of volunteers providing over 8,000 volunteer hours annually. 

In 2022, Street Angels achieved: 156 Nights of street outreach, 510 unique individuals met & provided resources, 103 individuals connected to housing, 78 safe sleeps in a hotel for our most vulnerable neighbors who were unable to access shelter, 14,292 hot meals served, offered 27 shower days and 203 showers, distributed 627 harm reduction kits, 9 unique treatment support partnerships established, they offered 15,527 bag lunches for latitudeer, received over $300,000 In-Kind items donated and had 2,289 financial donors. 

They're currently collaborating with Kohler to offer a mobile shower trailer by Spring, 2024. 

Let's help them reach more people! Please consider donating any of the items from their need list: https://www.streetangelsmke.org/donate 
Their Amazon wish list can be found here: https://www.amazon.com/hz/wishlist/ls/28S5E62D9SDUW/ref=nav_wishlist_lists_1

We'll be meeting at the Village Park Play Area in Menomonee Falls - a new, inclusive play area. Feel free to stay and explore the new park, walk the trail or grab a treat from Fiddleheads across the street. Pop's Frozen Custard and the Garcarde are nearby if you're looking to make an afternoon out of it!

classTitle: Animal Stories at Sharon Lynne Wilson Center
classDescription:
Come join us for a series of short Japanese animal stories acted out for kids, at Sharon Lynne Wilson Center for the Arts. This musical matinee will last just under an hour and is best for kids K5-2nd grade. 

These retellings of traditional fables and folktales from Japan and Okinawa teach important lessons of persistence, respect and kindness. Japanese and Okinawan music, language and culture are the heart of this performance featuring clever animals, puppetry, live songs, Koto and Taiko instruments, and a whole lot of fun for young audience members and their families. The five stories featured in the performance are part of the tradition of Mukashibanashi, or the “tales of long ago,” and include The Carp Who Would Not Quit, The Mice and the Rolling Musubi, the legend of the Rabbits making Mochi in the Moon, and more!

classDescription:
Learn how to make fun and easy fresh sushi rolls or, maki, for the whole family. Maki means “to roll” in Japanese. It’s a type of sushi made using rice cooked with vinegar, salt, and sugar wrapped with a layer of black seaweed (nori). 

For over a year, Ellie, age 12, has been making sushi rolls for her family using cooked sushi rice, vegetables, and seaweed. For this class, she will show you how to prepare your vegetables and assemble your ingredients to make about 6-8 rolls.

NOTE: Please prepare your sushi rice ahead of the class and have all supplies ready with a clean prep surface to work on. We will tell you how to season your rice at the class. 

We will go at a slow pace so no one will be confused or rushed.

classDescription:
Class Description: Would you like to learn how to make your very own pretzel from scratch?
Join us at Liv's Drink Emporium in Sun Prairie and be ready to learn how to mix, twist, and bake a homemade pretzel.
Please bring extra cash if you would like to purchase a drink or snack.
*If you have allergy concerns, please let us know. However, everything baked in the store may have cross contaminated with nuts*

displayLocation: Location: 929 East Wisconsin Ave Milwaukee WI 53202
classDescription: Class Description: We will start our visit in the Maker Space. Working in teams, we will learn about structure and shape and using real building materials we will construct (and maybe demolish!) a fort. Afterwards, we will have 1.5 hours for self guided play in the rest of the museum.

displayLocation: Location: 2894 N Erbe Rd, Blue Mounds, WI 53517
classDescription: Class Description: People of all ages will love getting to interact with all the animals at Haven's Petting Farm. From kittens and bunnies to ducks, cows and even a zebra, Haven's allows visitors to touch, feed and hold many of the animals at their farm. Located in the rolling hills of Blue Mounds, the farm offers pony rides, a hay maze and an amazing pit of corn for the kids to play in.

displayLocation: Location: 1979 Milky Way Verona WI
classDescription: Class Description: We will enjoy a 1 hour tour of the indoor and outdoor spaces of Epic Campus. Campus boasts buildings dedicated to such oddities as Alice in Wonderland, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Harry Potter and others. The art, and artistry is mind boggling!

classTitle: [MADISON]  F233700 Hoard Historical Museum Mystery of the Mounds
displayLocation: Location: 401 Whitewater Avenue Fort Atkinson WI 53538
classDescription: Class Description: Join us for a visit at the Hoard Museum in Fort Atkinson, with a focus on the Mysteries of the Mounds Exhibit. We will learn about the civilizations that lived in this area and the type of earthen mounds they built. We will also have some hands-on activities. We will get to hold and discuss some of the archeological tools and discoveries and brain storm what they might have been used for. We will also work in teams to build some structures using kinetic sand. We can have lunch on the lawn outside afterwards. If the weather does not cooperate, we can use a classroom upstairs. After lunch my family plans to go on a hike to see some of these mounds. We have a choice between Aztalan State Park (a state sticker or daily pass is required for parking) or the Effigy Mounds Preserve (free street parking).

classTitle: [MADISON] F234400 Monster Gelatin Brains and Cookie Bites
displayLocation: Location: Wyndham Hills Park , 675 N. Heatherstone Drive Sun Prairie, WI 53590
classDescription: Class Description: Let’s enjoy spooky season by playing in gelatin brains and by making monster treats. We will first whip up delicious monster energy bites with tasty ingredients but most importantly, candy monster eyes to finish them off. Later you’ll be able to eat your creations!

classTitle: [MADISON] F234700 Which is scarier? Dead or Alive???
displayLocation: Location: TBD on the Northside, in or near Warner Park
classDescription:
Class Description: Creepy creatures!
We've got both kinds: gross AND frightening; dead AND alive!
Face your fears!
Keepers of wicked-icky pets and makers of m̶a̶c̶a̶b̶r̶e̶ "creative" things with animal remains will show and tell about their...hobbies. And guess what, pets we call "creepy" can actually be quite nice!
See, touch, ask, learn. Then go home and beg a parent to fill your room with more creepy stuff? [Haha, parents! You get used to it.]
Feel free to bring your own (safe) creepy dead stuff or things made with creepy dead stuff for the Creepy Dead Stuff Showcase. :-)
